title-group.article-title: Breakpoint regions of an RHD-CE(4-9)-D allele and a rare JK allele in a Pacific Islander individual

contrib-group.aff: Department of Transfusion Medicine, NIH Clinical Center, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, United States of America

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence: Willy A. Flegel, e-mail: waf@nih.gov

license.license-p: Published under a CC BY-NC-ND license

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Among 710 RHD alleles, 3 alleles have been shown to express CcEe antigens and, among 67 hybrid alleles of the RHD gene, 2 alleles have evolved to include RHCE exons 4-9. No breakpoint region had been described for such RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid alleles. In the Kidd blood group system, the JK*02N.01 null allele is found with high prevalence in the Polynesian population. We investigated a self-identified Pacific Islander with discrepant serologic and molecular results for his C and Jkb antigens. Another 8 samples with genotype-phenotype discrepancies in the Kidd blood group system were assessed.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: A combination of published molecular methods and commercial kits were applied to analyze the RHD, RHCE, and SLC14A1 gene sequences, as were hemagglutination tests to determine the serologic phenotypes.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Nucleotide sequencing of the RHD gene in the index case, including relevant intron stretches, and cDNA identified an RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele. Nucleotide sequencing of his RHCE gene confirmed the presence of 2 RHCE*ce alleles despite expressing the C antigen. Sequencing of his SLC14A1 gene documented the JK*02N.01 null allele. In the other 8 samples, 5 previously known SLC14A1 nucleotide substitutions were identified. The JK*02N.17 allele was determined to be Jkb-positive.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We determined the 2 breakpoint regions of his RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele, which was likely distinct from the 2 previously published hybrid alleles due to the differences in the linked RHCE allele. His RHD variant was shown to express the C antigen. An SLC14A1 substitution was underlying his unexpected Jkb-negative phenotype. In a quality improvement project, we resolved 8 samples with similarly discrepant results between Jk serology and red cell genotyping.

award-group.funding-source: NIH Clinical Center at the National Institutes of Health

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The term Pacific Islander describes the ethnicity of inhabitants from the 3 geographically isolated South Pacific subregions of Oceania, known as Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia1. Several studies have noted indigenous populations of these Pacific island nations to harbor a high prevalence of rare blood group phenotypes2–4.

Incongruences between serologic and molecular results for blood groups may occur at rates of 0.1% or less5. They were recognized early on as mostly caused by technical or clerical errors while performing serology5. The remaining confirmed incongruences can typically be traced to rare or novel nucleotide substitutions5 that are not routinely recognized by molecular screening platforms6. Amino acid changes in blood group antigen carrying proteins due to single nucleotide variants (SNVs), nucleotide insertions or deletions and hybrid genes can cause epitope loss that may permit an immune response during allogeneic transfusion or pregnancy7. This may result in hemolytic transfusion reaction (HTR) or hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) and difficulty in finding compatible units7. Chimerism, the co-existence of cells from two different zygotes in a single organism8, is rare yet the typical cause of incongruencies when 2 or more blood group systems are affected in 1 individual, often showing mixed field agglutination on routine blood group typing8,9.

The RHD and RHCE genes, located on the short arm of chromosome 1 (1p36.11)10, encode the multi-pass transmembrane non-glycosylated proteins expressing the highly immunogenic DCcEe antigens of the RH blood group system (ISBT 004)7. RhD and RhCE proteins are expressed only in the membranes of red blood cells and their immediate precursors11. Antibodies to Rh antigens can cause severe HTR and HDFN12.

Expression of CcEe antigens from an altered RHD gene are known13–15 and D antigens from an altered RHCE gene have previously been observed16–23 or suspected24. The RH database25 lists 67 RHD-CE-D hybrid alleles, 2 of which are known to express partial CcEe antigens. The (C)ces haplotype, common in individuals of African ancestry26, expresses a C antigen caused by an RHD-CE-D hybrid allele (RHD*03N.01) of the RHD gene, where the RHD-specific exons 4 to 7 are replaced by their RHCE-specific counterparts13. Another RHD-CE-D hybrid allele (RHD*03N.02) in a D-negative African American blood donor, where the RHD-specific exons 4 to 9 are replaced by their RHCE-specific counterparts, likely expresses a C antigen, too15. Both hybrid alleles, RHD*03N.01 and RHD*03N.02, originated from the RHD*DIIIa allele (RHD*03.01) of the African DIVa cluster27. Breakpoint regions have only been released for RHD*03N.01 (5’ breakpoint region GenBank AX135857 and 3’ region AX135860 in 2001)28. While the RHD*03N.01 allele is known to produce allo-anti-C29; no such immunogenicity information is available for the RHD*03N.02 allele. Apart from these 2 hybrid alleles, the RHD allele DVII type 2 (RHD*07.02) harboring 2 missense SNVs has been shown to express a c antigen in 2 Caucasian blood donors14.

The RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele designation, which is defined by its complementary DNA (cDNA) and may include several distinct structures at the genomic DNA, has been observed in 9 DEL individuals from China30–32 with a Ce phenotype (RHD*01EL.44) and in 1 D-negative individual from Portugal33 with a cE phenotype (GenBank JQ918687). Because no adsorption/elution testing was reported33, the Portuguese sample could be a DEL. Both RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid alleles originated from the standard RHD allele (RHD*01) of the Eurasian D cluster34. No breakpoint regions had been defined for any such sample.

The human solute carrier family 14, member 1 (SLC14A1) gene, located on the long arm of chromosome 18 (18q12.3)35, encodes the multi-pass transmembrane glycosylated protein expressing only 3 known antigens, Jka, Jkb and Jk3, of the Kidd blood group system (JK, ISBT 009). SLC14A1 is primarily expressed on erythrocyte membrane and endothelium of the kidney36 and maintains osmotic homeostasis by functioning as a urea transporter37. Antibodies to Jk antigens can cause severe HTR and severe HDFN38. The ISBT database39 lists 62 SLC14A1 alleles that result in a weak expression of Jk antigens or the lack of any expression39.

We identified the 2 breakpoint regions of an RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele in a self-identified Pacific Islander, associated with a C antigen expression despite normal RHCE*ce alleles. He also presented with a Jkb-negative phenotype caused by a known splice-site variation in a JK*B allele of the SLC14A1 gene. In a quality improvement project, we further identified the SLC14A1 alleles in 8 individuals presenting at our service over a period of 12 years with genotype-phenotype discrepancies in the Kidd blood group system.

sec.title: Blood samples
sec.p: An EDTA-anticoagulated blood sample was obtained from an NIH blood donor with written informed donor consent, which includes red cell genotyping. He presented with an incongruence between serologic and molecular RhCE and Kidd (Jk) phenotypes at our routine blood group testing for donors. Another 8 individuals, whose blood samples were collected at our service between July 2011 and July 2023, presented with genotype-phenotype discrepancies of the Kidd blood group system. In a quality improvement project, we compared standard serology and molecular tests, including commercial kits and in-house sequencing.

sec.title: DNA and mRNA isolation
sec.p: Genomic DNA was isolated from the buffy coat (Qiagen EZ1 DNA blood kit on the BioRobot EZ1; Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA) and mRNA from RNA tubes (Dynabeads mRNA DIRECT kit; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA). The RHD mRNA was reverse transcribed to cDNA as described previously40.

sec.title: Immunohematology
sec.p: Hemagglutination tests for Rh and Jk antigens were performed by standard tube or gel matrix testing with licensed reagents (Ortho, Raritan, NJ; Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA; and Immucor, Norcross, GA, USA).

An adsorption/elution method with monoclonal anti-Jka (MS-15, Immucor or Ortho), polyclonal anti-Jka (lot no. PJKA-054, American Red Cross, Gaithersburg, MD, USA) and polyclonal anti-Jkb (lot no. PJKB-026, American Red Cross or lot no. 2623, Organon Teknika, Durham, NC, USA) was applied to test for the presence of weak Jk antigens41.

sec.title: Molecular screening of blood group genes
sec.p: For all repeat blood donors (≥2 donations) at the NIH blood bank, red cell genotyping was performed using the PreciseType HEA kit (human erythrocyte antigen; Immucor, Warren, NJ, USA).

sec.title: RHD, RHCE and SLC14A1 sequencing
sec.p: The nucleotide sequences of all the exons as well as adjacent intronic regions, including the 5’ and 3’ untranslated regions (UTR), were determined for RHD,42 RHCE42 and SLC14A143 genes. RHD cDNA was sequenced as described previously40. Zygosity testing for the RHD gene was done by restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP)44 and quantitative fluorescence polymerase chain reaction (QF-PCR)45. An allele-specific PCR was developed using the forward primers 5’-GTGCCACTAATGCAACAATGGGTAG-3′ (JkF3, sense) and 5’-GTGCCACTAATGCAACAATGGGTAC-3′ (JkF4, sense) with a common reverse primer 5’-CTCAATAGGCTCCTGCCTTCACAATC-3′ (Jk–i9+198, antisense)43 and applied in combination with nucleotide sequencing to analyze the SLC14A1 haplotype.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: A 59-year-old male blood donor at NIH self-identified as a Pacific Islander with a Caucasian mother (Spain) and an Asian father (Philippines). His routine serologic and molecular results for both the RhCE and Kidd (Jk) blood groups were incongruent. Using Sanger sequencing, we confirmed the commercial kit-based screening results and identified the underlying variant RHCE and SLC14A1 alleles that were not covered by the kits. In a quality improvement project, we also analyzed 8 samples with incongruent Jk antigen results.

sec.title: Serologic characterization and molecular screening
sec.p: The index case was O Rh D-positive and phenotyped as Rh Ccee and Jk(a+b−) by serology. No mixed field agglutination was observed. However, his molecular screening results indicated Rh ccee and Jk(a+b+).

sec.title: RHCE and RHD sequencing
sec.p: Nucleotide sequencing of his RHCE gene confirmed the presence of 2 homozygous normal RHCE*ce alleles. Zygosity testing and nucleotide sequencing of the RHD gene and cDNA identified a normal RHD allele in trans to an RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele (Table I). The exact breakpoint regions of the hybrid allele were determined, represented by 281 and 73 nucleotides at the 5’ and 3’ breakpoint regions, respectively (Figure 1). The sequence data for the hybrid allele was deposited in GenBank (OP804519) representing the concatenation of 354 nucleotides of the breakpoint region, 7,320 nucleotides of the RHD gene, and 9,081 nucleotides of the RHCE gene, including all CDS and splice site-near intron sequences, for a total of 16,755 nucleotides. We could, however, not determine the D antigen expression, such as RhD-positive, weak D, DEL or RhD-negative, with our sample because its RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele occurred in trans to a normal RHD*01 allele.

sec.title: SLC14A1 sequencing
sec.p: Nucleotide sequencing of the SLC14A1 gene confirmed the presence of a heterozygous SNV c.342-1G>A (rs78937798) located in intron 4 (Table I). Allele-specific PCR and subsequent nucleotide sequencing confirmed the c.342-1G>A variant of the JK*B allele (JK*02N.01) and the common JK*A allele (JK*01) in trans (Table II, Sample 1).

sec.title: Quality improvement of SLC14A1 sequencing
sec.p: Beside the index case, we searched for SLC14A1 nucleotide substitutions in another 8 individuals with variant Jk antigen expression (Online Supplementary Table SI). All 5 variant alleles found had been described before (Table II). The JK*A allele of Sample 2 was associated with a weak Jka antigen expression. JK*A null alleles were found in Samples 3 and 4, as were JK*B null alleles in Samples 5 to 7. The JK*02N.17 allele, supposedly representing a JK*B null allele46, was surprisingly expressing a normal Jkb antigen (Table II, Sample 4). Both samples 8 and 9 (Table II, see footnotes) were homozygous for the normal JK*A allele (JK*01).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The blood group antigens of the Pacific Islander were unique, because he simultaneously harbored variant antigens of the Rh and the Kidd blood group systems. We unequivocally defined the nucleotide breakpoint regions (Figure 1) for the third known example of an RHD-CE-D hybrid allele expressing an C antigen.

We initially suspected chimerism in the index case due to the co-occurrence of C antigen expression, despite the lack of an RHC allele, and of a JK*B allele, despite the lack of a Jkb antigen. However, no known RH and JK allele combination could explain the contradictory serologic and molecular results, assuming a chimerism involving common alleles. Other reasons to exclude chimerism were the absence of any mixed field agglutination for red cell antigens, any history of therapeutic transfusion or stem cell transplantation and any knowledge of a twin. We rejected chimerism as an explanation once a rare SLC14A1 allele explaining the Jk blood group incongruence was recognized.

The splice site substitution c.342-1G>A within the SLC14A1 gene in the index case has been reported with high prevalence in the Polynesian population47. The SNV is located at the conserved 3′-acceptor site in intron 4 and cause skipping of exon 5 in the SLC14A1 mRNA48 abolishing the expression of the associated protein. The SLC14A1 SNV c.342-1G>A was not implemented in the red cell genotyping kits that were routinely used in our laboratory (RBC-FluoGene vERYfy eXtend or the FDA-approved PreciseType HEA). However, the ID CORE XT platform detected this variant50 and would be more suitable for analyzing individuals with Polynesian ethnic background.

With identical RHD mRNA structure yet different ethnic origins and Rh haplotypes, the 3 RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrids sharing the primordial RHD*01 allele (Table III) likely arose by independent gene conversion events. DNA recombination or gene conversion events affecting splice-sites, coding sequences, or regulatory elements generate novel hybrid alleles and are known mechanisms for antigenic diversity, notably in the RH and MNS blood group systems15,51. The expression of D and CE antigens by RHD-CE-D hybrid alleles may, however, differ despite identical mRNA structure, because the precise location of the breakpoint region affects the expression and stability of mRNA transcripts by various mechanisms (Table IV). Hybrid alleles that are seemingly identical based on their mRNA need to be distinguished in clinical blood transfusion practice, because they may still result in any D phenotype, such as RhD-negative, DEL, weak D or RhD-positive. The structure of the RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid alleles may involve enhancer, transcription factor binding sites and the coding sequence (CDS) and can consequently affect all 5 mechanisms, except ectopic expression (Table IV).

In a quality improvement project, we delineated 5 SNVs in the SLC14A1 gene as the molecular basis of variant expression of Jk antigens in 6 individuals (Table II, Samples 2 to 7). In samples 8 and 9, technical errors of the initial results were identified and corrected (Table II, footnotes). All 5 SNVs were known before. One sample was even a compound heterozygote harboring 1 non-synonymous SNV c.582C>G52 and 1 synonymous SNV c.810G>A46,53. Allele-specific amplification and subsequent sequencing confirmed c.582C>G to be in cis with the JK*01 allele and c.810G>A in cis with the JK*02 allele. The c.582C>G substitution results in a premature stop codon (p.Tyr194Stop) and was found in a Swiss Jknull propositus and her sister52. The c.810G>A synonymous substitution (p.Ala270Ala) have been associated with Jka null phenotype in 2 patients53 and Jkb null phenotype in 2 blood donors46. A recent study raised questions on the interpretation whether c.810G>A substitution, present at the exon-intron boundary, causes any Jknull phenotype54. Using allele specific amplification in a Jk(a−b+) donor (Table II, Sample 4), we corroborated the previously published observation54 that c.810G>A is a neutral substitution, at least when present on the JK*B allele, and concur with their conclusion that the null allele JK*02N.17 should be relabeled as a fully functional allele54.

Our study exemplifies the importance of identifying precise breakpoint regions in hybrid alleles at the level of primary genomic DNA structure, which is critical to predict clinically relevant antigens. Breakpoints offer crucial advantages for next-generation sequencing (NGS) data analysis and should be provided online as suitably annotated nucleotide sequences, typically as a concatenation of the relevant stretches that are diagnostic for the allele (for example GenBank OP804519). The ease to detect and analyze phenotypic effects of distinct chromosomal breakpoint regions in human blood group genes suggest itself as a study model. This approach offers an opportunity for transfusion medicine because the results may eventually be translated to other hybrid alleles of genes involved in a multitude of human diseases including cancer, where the phenotypic effects of hybrid alleles are more difficult to investigate.

We defined the breakpoint regions for an RHD-CE(4-9)-D allele. Commercial red cell genotyping kits still have limitations in correctly predicting the antigens expressed by hybrid RH and rare JK alleles. The identification of the breakpoints will allow researchers to design PCR assays for the targeted screening of these deletions. Knowledge of the exact sequence will assist in identifying the clinically relevant RHD alleles, especially when applying high throughput technologies. A quality improvement project prompted us to establish a standard operating procedure (SOP) for SLC14A1 genotyping, allowing to routinely resolve discrepancies between serology and red cell genotyping kits in the Kidd blood group system. We corroborated the molecular structure of the, erroneously labeled “non-functional”39,46, JK*02N.17 allele expressing a Jkb-positive phenotype.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
ack.p: We thank Traci D. Paige MT(ASCP)SBB for sample coordination and Nuri Cha MS, CHS(ACHI) and the staff of HLA laboratory for technical assistance. This work was supported by the Intramural Research Program (project ID ZIC CL002128) of the NIH Clinical Center at the National Institutes of Health.

fn.p: AUTHORSHIP CONTRIBUTION: WAF designed the study approach and developed the rationales. MUB performed the serology tests and analyzed the data with WAF. KS designed and performed the molecular experiments, retrieved literature and wrote drafts. KS analyzed the molecular data with WAF. WAF discussed the data and wrote the final manuscript.
STATEMENT OF DISCLAIMER: The views expressed do not necessarily represent the view of the National Institutes of Health, the Department of Health and Human Services, or the U.S. Federal Government.
The Authors declare no conflicts interest.
FUNDING: This work was supported by the Intramural Research Program (project ID ZIC CL002128) of the NIH Clinical Center at the National Institutes of Health.

caption.p: Schematic representation of the genomic structure of the RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele (GenBank no. OP 804519)

The RHD gene (orange) comprises 10 exons (black bars) flanked by the upstream (blue) and downstream Rhesus box (red). The RHD-specific exons 4 to 9 are replaced by their RHCE-specific counterparts (olive green) forming a RHD-CE(4-9)-D hybrid allele of the RHD gene. The chromosomal positions flanking the 2 breakpoint regions of 281 and 73 bp are indicated based on the reference sequence NC_000001.11.
RHD and SLC14A1 alleles of the self-identified Pacific Islander†

fn.p: See Table II for further details (Sample 1).
mRNA coordinates based on NM_016124.6 for RHD and NM_015865.7 for SLC14A1 and protein coordinates on NP_057208.3 for RhD and NP_056949.4 for SLC14A1.

caption.p: Serologic reactivity and SLC14A1 alleles identified in 9 individuals†

fn.p: Including the index case (sample 1), and 8 individuals (samples 2–9) with discrepancies in the Kidd blood group system between serologic typing and red cell genotyping, which were all resolved by the workup.
Relative to NCBI Reference Sequence NG_011775.4. mRNA coordinates are based on NM_015865.7 and protein coordinates on NP_056949.4.
Identical results were obtained with the RBC-FluoGene vERYfy eXtend kit (Inno-Train Diagnostik, Kronberg, Germany).
The Jka antigen was weakly positive with polyclonal anti-Jka (PJKA-054) but negative with monoclonal anti-Jka (clone MS-15, Immucor, Norcross, GA, USA).
Based on our results, corroborating previous data53, the null allele JK*02N.17 should be relabeled as a functional allele expressing Jkb phenotype.
Initially typed as mixed field with anti-Jkb. A fresh sample was drawn the next day and typed as Jk(a+b−).
Repeat testing with PreciseType of the sample indicated Jk(a+b−) and sequencing was performed to corroborate the result.

caption.p: Possible functional effects of the distinct location of breakpoint regions in hybrid alleles

fn.p: These modifications can affect when the RHD hybrid allele is expressed during erythropoiesis and how it is expressed causing phenotypes such as RhD-negative, DEL, weak D or RhD-positive.
